children.name: Definition of Bill of Rights
children.enum1: The set of prescriptions setting forth the fundamental civil and political rights of the individual, and imposing limitations on the powers of government as a means of securing the enjoyment of those rights.
children.enum2: The Bill of Rights is designed to preserve the ideals of liberty, equality and security “against the assaults of opportunism, the expediency of the passing hour, the erosion of small encroachments, and the scorn and derision of those who have no patience with general principles.
children.enum3: Generally, any governmental action in violation of the Bill of Rights is void. These provisions are also generally self executing.

children.name: Civil Rights
children.enum1: Those rights that belong to every citizen of the state or country, or, in a wider sense, to all its inhabitants, and are not connected with the organization or administration of government. They include the rights to property, marriage, equal protection of the laws, freedom of contract, etc.. They are rights appertaining to a person by virtue of his citizenship in a state or community. Such term may also refer, in its general sense, to rights capable of being enforced or redressed in a civil action.

children.name: Political Rights
children.enum1: They refer to the right to participate, directly or indirectly, in the establishment or administration of government, e.g., the right of suffrage, the right to hold public office, the right to petition and, in general the rights appurtenant to citizenship visa-visthe management of government

children.name: Effect of Absence of the Bill of Rights
children.details: Republic v. Sandiganbayan, G.R. No. 104768, July 21, 2003
children.enum1: The Supreme Court held that the Bill of Rights under the 1973 Constitution was not operative from the actual and effective take-over of power by the revolutionary government following the EDSA revolution until the adoption, on March 24, 1986, of the Provisional (Freedom) Constitution. During this period, the directives and orders of the revolutionary government were the supreme law, because no constitution limited the extent and scope of such directives and orders. Thus, during the interregnum, a person could not invoke any exclusionary right under the Bill of Rights, because there was neither a constitution nor a Bill of Rights at the time. However, the protection accorded to individuals under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights(ICCPR) and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) remained in effect during the interregnum.

children.name: Section 1
children.enum1: No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property without due process of law, nor shall any person be denied the equal protection of the laws.

children.name: Definitions
children.details: The concept of due process was not given exact definition for resiliency. Due process is not like some provisions, an 'iron rule' laying down an implacable and immutable command for all seasons and all persons. Flexibility must be the best virtue of the guaranty

children.name: Justice Felix Frankfurter
children.enum1: the embodiment of the sporting idea of fair play.

children.name: Daniel Webster in the Darthmouth Case
children.enum1: the law which hears before it condemns, which proceeds upon inquiry and renders judgment only after trial.
children.enum2: Reason: It has to be so if the rights of every person are to be secured beyond the reach of officials who, out of mistaken zeal or plain arrogance, would degrade the due process clause into a worn and empty catchword. (This definition is on procedural aspect)

children.name: Justice Enrique M. Fernando in Galman v. Pamaran
children.enum1: due process ... is responsiveness to the supremacy of reason, obedience to the dictates of justice. Negatively put, arbitrariness is ruled out and unfairness avoided. To satisfy the due process requirement, official action, to paraphrase Cardozo, must not outrun the bounds of reason and result in sheer oppression. Due process is thus hostile to any official action marred by lack of reasonableness. Correctly, it has been identified as freedom from arbitrariness. It is the embodiment of the sporting Idea of fair play ... It exacts fealty 'to those strivings for justice' and judges the act of officialdom of whatever branch 'in the light of reason drawn from considerations of fairness that reflect (democratic) traditions of legal and political thought.' ... It is not a narrow or 'technical conception with fixed content unrelated to time, place and circumstances,' ... decisions based on such a clause requiring a 'close and perceptive inquiry into fundamental principles of our society.'... Questions of due process are not to be treated narrowly or pedantically in slavery to form or phrases. ....

children.name: Justice Isagani Cruz
children.enum1: Due process is a guaranty against any arbitrariness on the part of the government, whether committed by the legislative, the executive, or the judiciary.
children.enum2: The essence of due process is distilled in the immortal cry of Themistocles to Alcibiades 'Strike — but hear me first!'

children.name: Effects of Violation of Due Process
children.enum1: 1. Substantive
children.enum2: -unconstitutional
children.enum3: 2. Procedural
children.enum4: -invalid proceedings. the governmental act will be invalid, but the law will still be valid.

children.name: Substantive Due Process
children.enum1: this serves as a restriction on the government’s law and rulemaking powers. It requires the intrinsic validity of the law in interfering with the rights of the person to his life, liberty or property. (CRUZ);
children.enum2: It must be a guarantee against the exercise of arbitrary power even when the power is exercised according to proper forms and procedure (BERNAS)

children.name: Requisites
children.enum1: a. There must be a valid Law upon which it is based;
children.enum2: b. The law must have been passed or approved to accomplish a valid government objective;
children.enum3: c. The objective must be pursued in a lawful manner; and
children.enum4: d. The law as well as the Means to accomplish the objective must be valid and not oppressive.
children.enum6: Note: Publication of laws is part of substantive due process

children.name: Procedural Due Process
children.enum1: it serves as a restriction on actions of judicial and quasijudicial agencies of the government (BERNAS)
children.enum2: a guarantee of procedural fairness; it refers to the regular methods of procedure to be observed before one’s life, liberty or property can be taken away from him. Simply stated, it means the procedure to be observed must be fair. (SUAREZ)

children.name: Aspects of Procedural Due Process
children.enum1: 1. Procedural Due Process in Judicial Proceedings
children.enum2: 2. Procedural Due Process in Administrative Proceedings
children.enum3: 3. Procedural Due Process in School Proceedings

children.name: Requisites of Administrative Due Process
children.enum1: (1) Right to a hearing, to present one’s cause and submit evidence in support thereof;
children.enum2: (2) The tribunal must consider the evidence presented;
children.enum3: (3) The decision must have something to support itself;
children.enum5: (5) The decision must be based on evidence presented at the hearing or contained in the record and disclosed to the parties;
children.enum6: (6) Judges must act on its own Independent Consideration of the law and facts of the controversy; and
children.enum7: (7) the decision must have something to support itself.

children.name: Requisites of Educational Institution Due Process
children.enum1: (1) The students must be informed in writing of the nature and cause of any accusation against them;
children.enum2: (2) They shall have the right to answer the charges against them with the assistance of a counsel, if desired;
children.enum3: (3) They shall be informed of the evidence against them;
children.enum4: (4) They shall have the right to adduce evidence in their own behalf; and
children.enum5: (5) the evidence must be duly considered by the investigating committee.

children.name: Ichong vs. Hernandez
children.enum1: a. The due process clause has to do with the reasonableness of legislation enacted in pursuance of police power. The test of reasonableness of a law is the appropriateness or adequacy under all circumstances of the means adopted to carry out its purpose into effect.
children.enum2: b. The conflict between police power and due process of laws is more apparent than real. Property related, the powers and guarantees must coexist. The balancing is the essence or, shall it be said, the indispensable means for the attainment of legitimate aspirations of any democratic society. The test or standards, as always, is reason.

children.name: Two Evils Sought to be Prevented by Equa
children.enum1: 1. undue favor and invidivual or class privilege
children.enum2: 2. hostile discrimination

children.name: Philippine Phosphate Fertilizer Corp. vs. Torres
children.enum1: The right to hearing as an element of due process does not call for a trial type hearing. The essence of due process is simply the right to be heard, an opportunity to explain one’s side or an opportunity to seek reconsideration of the action complained of.

children.name: Ynot vs. Intermediate Appellate Court
children.enum1: The concept of due process was not given exact definition for resiliency. Due process is not like some provisions, an 'iron rule' laying down an implacable and immutable command for all seasons and all persons. Flexibility must be the best virtue of the guaranty

children.name: Exceptions to Notice and Hearing
children.details: Due process is the embodiment of the sporting idea of fair play. The minimum requirements are notice and hearing subject to exceptions:
children.enum1: (1) Conclusive presumption;
children.enum2: (2) Summary abatement of a nuisance per se;
children.enum3: (3) Passport of a person sought for a criminal offense; and
children.enum4: (4) Filthy restaurants—because of the nature of the property and urgency of the need to protect the general welfare from clear and present danger.

children.name: Alonte vs. Savellano
children.enum1: Due process rightly occupies the first and foremost place of honor in our Bill of Rights, is an enshrined and valuable right that cannot be denied even to the most undeserving.

children.name: Due Process in Criminal Proceedings
children.details: Due process in Criminal Proceedings particularly require:
children.enum1: (1) That the court or tribunal trying the case is properly clothed with judicial power to hear and determine the matter before it;
children.enum2: (2) That jurisdiction is lawfully acquired by it over the person of the accused;
children.enum3: (3) The accused is given an opportunity to be heard; and
children.enum4: (4) Judgment is rendered only upon lawful hearing.

children.name: How is jurisdiction acquired?
children.enum1: By the tribunal - Confered by law.
children.enum2: Over the person of the accused - arrest, surrender, entering a plea

children.name: Aniag vs. COMELEC
children.enum1: a. The right to preliminary investigation, although it does not emanate from the Constitution is an essential element of criminal due process. The essence of due process is the reasonable opportunity to be heard and to submit any evidence one may have in support of his defense.
children.enum2: b. Due process guarantees the observance of both substantive and procedural rights from whatever source, be it the Constitution or only a statute.

children.enum1: Here, there is violation of procedural due process only whick invalidated the proceeding and not the gun ban law.

children.name: Spouses Romualdez vs. COMELEC
children.enum1: a. The jurisdiction of the Court is determined by the allegations in the complaint or information, and not by the evidence presented by the parties.

children.name: Inapplicability of Strict Scrutiny, Overbreadth, and Vagueness
children.enum1: b. The Doctrines of Strict Scrutiny, Overbreadth, and Vagueness are analytical tools developed for testing on their faces, statutes in Free Speech Cases. They cannot be made to do service when what is involved is a criminal statute. Otherwise, it would result to mass acquittal of parties whose cases may not have even reach the Courts. Such invalidation would constitute a departure from the usual requirement of “actual case” and controversy, and permit decision to be made in sterile abstract having no factual correctness. Under no case may ordinary penal statutes be subjected to a facial challenge.

children.name: Philippine Communications Satellite Corp. vs. Alcuaz
children.enum1: a. Rate-fixing power exercised in a quasi-judicial manner requires prior notice and hearing. Such rate fixing, although temporary, is not exempt from the statutory procedural requirements of notice and hearing, as well as the requirement of reasonableness.

children.name: Notice and Hearing in Administrative Bodies
children.enum1: b. However, where the function of the administrative body is LEGISLATIVE, notice and hearing is not required by due process. But where a public administrative body acts in a judicial or quasi-judicial matter, and it acts are particular and immediate rather than general and prospective, the person whose rights or property may be affected by the action is entitled to notice and hearing.

children.name: Quasijudicial vs Quasilegislative
children.enum1: If the subject of the order is specific, it is quasijudicial.
children.enum2: If it is general, it is quasilegislative.

children.name: Ang Tibay vs. Court of Industrial Relations
Requisites of Administrative Due Process
children.enum1: (1) Right to a hearing, to present one’s cause and submit evidence in support thereof;
children.enum2: (2) The tribunal must consider the evidence presented;
children.enum3: (3) The decision must have something to support itself;
children.enum5: (5) The decision must be based on evidence presented at the hearing or contained in the record and disclosed to the parties;
children.enum6: (6) Judges must act on its own Independent Consideration of the law and facts of the controversy; and
children.enum7: (7) the decision must have something to support itself.

children.name: Ateneo de Manila vs. Capulong
children.enum1: An administrative proceeding conducted to investigate a hazing incident need not be clothed with the attributes of a judicial proceeding. Respondent students have no right to examine affiants-neophytes.

children.name: Requisites of Educational Institution Due Process
children.enum1: (1) The students must be informed in writing of the nature and cause of any accusation against them;
children.enum2: (2) They shall have the right to answer the charges against them with the assistance of a counsel, if desired;
children.enum3: (3) They shall be informed of the evidence against them;
children.enum4: (4) They shall have the right to adduce evidence in their own behalf; and
children.enum5: (5) the evidence must be duly considered by the investigating committee.

children.name: Southern Hemisphere Engagement Network, Inc. vs. Anti-Terrorism Council
Vagueness Doctrine
children.enum1: A statute or act suffers from the defect of vagueness when it lacks comprehensible standards the men of common intelligence must necessarily guess its meaning and differ as to its application.

children.name: Aspects
children.details: It is repugnant to the Constitution in two aspects:
children.enum1: (1) It violates due process for failure to accord persons, especially the parties targeted by it, fair notice of the conduct to avoid; and
children.enum2: (2) It leaves law enforces unbridled discretion in carrying out its provisions and becomes arbitrary flexing the Government muscle.

children.name: Overbreadth Doctrine
children.details: It decrees that a governmental purpose to control or prevent activities constitutionally subject to state regulations may not be achieved by means which sweep unnecessarily broadly and thereby invade the area of protected freedoms.

children.name: c. Facial Challenge
children.enum1: An examination of the entire law, pinpointing its flaws and defects, not only on the basis of its actual operation to the parties, but also on the assumption or prediction that its very existence may cause others not before the court to refrain from constitutionally protected speech or activities.

children.name: As Applied Challenge
children.enum1: It considers only extant facts affecting real litigants.
children.enum2: All requisites of judicial inquiry is present. The person who challenges is the person charged with violation of the law.

children.name: Mosqueda vs. Pilipino Banana Growers & Exporters Association

children.enum1: Here, the law was declared unconstitutional for violation of substantive due process.

children.name: Equal Protection
children.enum1: All persons and things similarly situated must be similarly treated as to both rights conferred and to responsibilities imposed. It does not demand absolute equality.

children.name: Classification
children.enum1: It means the grouping of persons or things similar to each other in certain particulars and different from all others in the same particulars.

children.name: Requisites of Reasonable Classification
children.enum1: 1. Such classification rests upon substantial distinction
children.enum2: 2. It applies equally to the same members of the same class.
children.enum3: 3. It is germane to the purposes of the law; and
children.enum4: 4. It is not confined to existing conditions only.

children.name: Underinclusiveness Doctrine
children.enum1: Insufficiency cannot be cured when the discrimination is not by oversight, but deliberate.

children.name: Facial Invalidation
children.enum1: Allowed if the ground is based on the absence of the 3rd requisite of reasonable classification  (not confined to existing conditions only)

children.name: PASEI v. Drilon
children.enum1: VAWC -

children.name: Stare Decisis
children.enum1: does not apply in cases involving classification. Reasonableness is determined from the facts of the case.
children.enum2: but if the classification creates favorable situation for the group, it is valid.

children.name: Tests in Determining the Reasonableness of Classification
children.correlation: Spark v. Quezon City, Mosqueda v. Banana Growers
children.details: In addition to the requisites of classification, the court must apply these three levels of scrutiny
children.enum1: 1. Rational Basis Test
children.enum2: 2. Intermediate Scrutiny Test
children.enum3: 3. Strict Scrutiny Test

children.name: Rational Basis Test
children.enum1: the rational basis test applies to all other subjects not covered by the first two tests.
children.enum2: the rational basis scrutiny is not based on a simple means-purpose correlation; nor does the rational basis scrutiny automatically result in a presumption of validity of the ordinance or deference to the wisdom of the local legislature. 148 To reiterate, aside from ascertaining that the means and purpose of the ordinance are reasonably related, the classification should be based on a substantial distinction.
children.enum3: The rational basis scrutiny (also known as the rational relation test or rational basis test) demands that the classification reasonably relate to the legislative purpose. The rational basis test often applies in cases involving economics or social welfare, 128 or to any other case not involving a suspect class.

children.name: Intermediate Scrutiny Test
children.enum1: Applied when the classification imposes a burden on a suspect class.
children.enum2: The intermediate scrutiny test applies when a classification does not involve suspect classes or fundamental rights, but requires heightened scrutiny, such as in classifications based on gender and legitimacy.
children.enum3: When the classification puts a quasi-suspect class at a disadvantage, it will be treated under intermediate or heightened review. Classifications based on gender or illegitimacy receives intermediate scrutiny.
children.enum4: To survive intermediate scrutiny, the law must not only further an important governmental interest and be substantially related to that interest, but the justification for the classification must be genuine and must not depend on broad generalizations.

children.name: Strict Scrutiny Test
children.enum1: Applied when the classification interferes with the exercise of substantive right
children.enum2: State must show that it has substantive interest and that it was not narrowly drawn
children.enum4: The strict scrutiny test applies when a classification either (i) interferes with the exercise of fundamental rights, including the basic liberties guaranteed under the Constitution, or (ii) burdens suspect classes.
children.enum5: the strict scrutiny review applies when a legislative classification impermissibly interferes with the exercise of a fundamental right or operates to the peculiar class disadvantage of a suspect class. The Government carries the burden to prove that the classification is necessary to achieve a compelling state interest, and that it is the least restrictive means to protect such interest.

children.name: Doctrine of Relative Constitutionality or Principle of Altered Circumstance
People vs. Vera
children.details: Probation Law -Appropriation for Parol Officers
children.enum1: A law may appear fair on its face or impartial in appearance, yet, if it permits unjust and illegal discrimination, it is still subject to the Constitutional prohibition.
children.enum2: There is no difference between a law which denies equal protection and a law which permits of such denial.
children.enum3: Class legislation discriminating against some and favoring others is prohibited. But classification on a reasonable basis, and not made arbitrarily or capriciously is permitted.

children.name: Yik Woo
children.enum1: If applied and administered with uneven eyes and hand, there is
children.enum2: No difference between law that discriminates and a law that allows discrimination.

children.enum1: No need to wait for actual discrimination.

children.name: Ichong vs. Hernandez
children.details: Retail Trade
children.enum1: 1935 Constitution contains Parity Provisions - so in the eyes of the law, American citizens enjoy the same privileges oas Filipinos which create distinction with other alients

children.name: Villegas vs. Hiu Chiong Tsai Pao Ho
children.details: Uniform Employment Fee
children.enum1: A law that does not specify the manner of exercise of discrimination is violative of the equal protection clause.
children.enum2: While it is true that the Philippines as a State is not obliged to admit aliens within its territory, once an alien is admitted, he cannot be deprived of life without due process of law.

children.name: People vs. Cayat
children.details: Non Christian Tribes
children.enum1: When the public safety or the public morals require the discontinuance of a certain practice by a certain class of persons, the hand of the Legislature cannot be stayed from providing for its discontinuance by any incidental inconvenience which some members of the class may suffer.
Classification here is based on the level of civilization.
children.enum2: Members of indiginous tribes are more likely to be more violent in consumption of alcohol.

children.name: Requisites of Equal Protection:
children.enum1: (1) Must rest on substantial distinctions;
children.enum2: (2) Must be germane to the purpose of the law;
children.enum3: (3) Must not be limited to existing conditions only; and
children.enum4: (4) Must apply equally to all members of the same class.

children.name: Dumlao vs. COMELEC
children.enum1: Age is a valid classification in government service.
children.enum2: The equal protection clause does not forbid all legal classifications. What is proscribed is a classification which is arbitrary and unreasonable.

children.name: Philippine Association of Service Exporters vs. Drilon
children.enum1: Gender is a valid classification.
children.enum2: Equality before the law does not import a perfect identity of rights among all men and women.
children.enum3: What the Constitution prohibits is the singling out of a select person or group within an existing class to the prejudice of such person resulting in an unfair advantage to another person or group of persons.

children.name: Himagan vs. People
children.details: Preventive suspension
children.enum1: Police officers may be distinguished from other civil servants without violating equal protection clause since they carry weapons and the badge of the law which can be used to harass or intimidate witnesses against them.
children.enum2: The equal protection clause exists to prevent undue favor or privilege. Recognizing the existence of real differences among men, the equal protection clause does not demand absolute equality.

children.name: Indefiniteness on Preventive Suspension for Police Officers
children.enum1: Active police officers may interfere with the investigation of his case.

children.name: Quinto vs. COMELEC
children.enum1: There is a valid classification between elected and appointed government officials.
children.enum2: An elected official is not deemed to have resigned from his office upon the filing of his Certificate of Candidacy for the same or any other elected office or position.
children.enum3: Substantial distinctions exist between elective and appointive officials. The former occupy their office by virtue of the mandate of the electorate. They are elected to an office for a definite term and may be removed therefrom only upon stringent conditions. Appointive officials hold their office by virtue of their designation thereto by an appointing authority.

children.name: Deemed Resigned
children.enum1: The Civil Service provision cannot be applied to elected officials because such are already engaged in partisan political activity from the first day in office.

children.name: Biraogo vs. The Philippine Truth Commission
children.enum1: The concept of equal justice under the law requires that the State govern impartially, and it may not draw distinctions between individuals solely on differences that are irrelevant to legitimate governmental objectives.
children.enum2: Superficial differences do not make for a valid classification. For a classification to meet the requirements of constitutionality, it must include or embrace all persons who naturally belong to the class.
children.enum3: The mere fact that an individual belonging to a class differs from the other members, as long as that class is substantially distinguishable from all others, does not justify the non-application of the law to him.
children.enum4: The Equal Protection Clause does not forbid discrimination as to things that are different. It does not prohibit legislation which is limited either in the object to which it is directed or by territory within which to operate.
children.enum5: Legislation is not unconstitutional merely because it is not allembracing and does not include all evils within its reach. It has been written that a regulation challenged under the equal protection clause is not devoid of a rational predicate simply because it happens to be incomplete. Underexclusiveness is not a ground to invalidate a law.
children.enum6: A legislature does not run the risk of losing the entire remedial scheme simply because it fails, through inadvertence or otherwise, to cover every evil that might conceivably have been attacked.

children.name: Almonte vs. Vazquez
children.enum1: Acceptance of unsigned complainants against a government official before the Ombudsman does not amount to unjust discrimination.
children.enum2: It is the Constitution itself which expressly enjoins the Ombudsman to act on any complaint filed in any form or manner concerning official acts or omissions. The same is because of the well-known reticence of the people which keep them from complaining against official wrongdoings.

children.name: Ormoc Sugar Co., Inc. vs. Treasurer of Ormoc City
children.enum1: The classification to be reasonable, should be in terms applicable to future conditions as well.

children.name: Section 2
children.enum1: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects against unreasonable searches and seizures of whatever nature and for any purpose shall be inviolable, and no search warrant or warrant of arrest shall issue except upon probable cause to be determined personally by the judge after examination under oath or affirmation of the complainant and the witnesses he may produce, and particularly describing the place to be searched and the persons or things to be seized.

children.name: Two Parts of Section 2
children.enum1: 1. The constitutional guarantee against unreasonable searches and seizures; and
children.enum2: 2. Requisites of valid search warrant or warrant of arrest

children.name: The constitutional guarantee against unreasonable searches and seizures
Nature of the Search
children.enum1: Personal.
children.enum2: It can only be invoked by the person whose rights are violated.

children.name: General Warrant & Scattershot Warrant
children.enum1: General Warrant is prohibited
children.enum2: Sec 4, Rule 126 - in relation to one specific offense. The article or section must be specified.
children.enum3: When a special law only punishes one offense, reference to the title is particular enough.

children.name: Factors to Consider in Determining Reasonableness of the Search and Seizure (can be extended to Arrest)
children.enum1: circumstances involved
children.enum2: 1. pupose of search
children.enum3: 2. presence or absence of probable cause
children.enum4: 3. manner in which the search and seizure was made

children.name: Requisites of valid search warrant or warrant of arrest
children.enum1: 1. Existence of Probable Cause
children.enum2: 2. Must be issued for 1 specific offense
children.enum3: 3. Probable cause was personally determined by the Judge
children.enum4: 4. Personal examination under oath or affirmation of the complainant and the witnesses he may produce
children.enum5: 5. Personal knowledge of the complainant or his witnesses of the facts
children.enum6: 6. Particular description of the place to be searched and the persons or things to be seized

children.name: Existence of Probable Cause
children.enum1: What is probable cause in general?

children.name: Must be issued for 1 specific offense
Probable cause was personally determined by the Judge
Personal examination under oath or affirmation of the complainant and the witnesses he may produce
Section, Art. 7
children.details: Distinction between Oath or Affirmation
children.enum1: oath - i do solemnly swear ... so help me god
children.enum2: affirmation - i do solemnly affirm ...

children.name: Personal knowledge of the complainant or his witnesses of the facts
Particular description of the place to be searched and the persons or things to be seized

children.enum1: description is sufficiently particular when the officer serving such warrant
children.enum2: particularity is sufficient when any police officer may execute it

children.name: Rules of Procedure
children.enum1: Rules of Court do not define a warrant of arrest, so the two provisions( 126 & 113) must be considered to make a definition.
children.enum2: Prescription
children.enum3: Scope
children.enum4: Distinction between Warrant of Arrest and Search Warrant

children.name: Rule 113
children.enum1: 10 day period

children.name: People vs. Marti
children.details: Four Gift Wrapped Package Opened by Wife

children.enum1: The constitutional guarantee against unreasonable searches and seizures applies only to government interference and cannot be invoked against private intrusions
children.enum2: The Bill of Rights governs the relationship between the individual and the State. Its concern is not the relation between individuals, and other individuals. What the Bill of Rights does is to declare some forbidden zones in the private sphere inaccessible to any power holder.
children.enum3: he protection against unreasonable searches and seizures cannot be extended to acts committed by private individuals so as to bring it within the ambit of alleged unlawful intrusion by the Government.

children.enum1: The mere presence of governmental entity did not convert the reasonable search effected by Reyes into a warrantless search and seizure proscribed by the Constitution. Merely to observe and look at which is in plain sight is not search.
children.enum2: But if the search is made upon the request of law enforcers, a warrant must generally be first secured. If made at the behest of the proprietor of private establishment for its own and private purposes, and without intervention of the authorities, the right against unreasonable searches and seizure cannot be invoked.
children.enum3: The law refers to law enforcement officers engaged in the investigation of crimes and not all public officers.

children.name: Stonehill vs. Diokno
children.details: 42 Search Warrants

children.enum1: The right against unreasonable searches and seizures is a personal one. It can be contested only by the person whose rights have been impaired thereby.
The warrant to search the office of the corporation cannot be challenged by the stockholders since there must be a board resolution for a corporation to act.

General warrants are outlawed because they place the sanctity of domicile and privacy of communication and correspondence at the mercy of the whims, caprice, and passion of the peace officers. The explicit command of our Bill of Rights is that this to be seized be particularly described.
The Exclusionary Rule is the only practical means of enforcing the Constitutional injunction against unreasonable searches and seizures.

children.name: Mantaring vs. Judge Roman
children.details: Unlicensed Firearm
children.enum1: Judges can no longer conduct preliminary investigation. Therefore, WOA can only be issued after the filing of the criminal complaint. There is no more WOA issued in preliminary investigation.

The issuance of search warrants and warrant of arrest requires the showing of probabilities as to different facts. But persons named in warrant of arrest need not be included in the search warrant for prosecution of the offense.

children.details: Probable Cause; Search Warrant
children.enum1: The determination of probable cause must be based on the finding that the articles to be seized are connected to a criminal activity and they are found in the place to be searched. It is not necessary that a particular person be impleaded.

children.details: Probable Cause; Warrant of Arrest
children.enum1: It is based on a finding that a crime has been committed and that the person to be arrested has committed it. The investigating judge must examine in writing, and under oath the complainant and his witnesses by searching questions and answers, and be satisfied that there is probable cause. Also, there must exist a need to place the respondent under immediate custody in order not to frustrate the ends of justice.

children.name: Search Warrants
children.enum1: Stricter because there is no preliminary investigation in the issueance of a search warrant.

For WARRANT OF ARREST, judges are not required to personally examine the complainant and his witnesses. He is only mandated to personally evaluate the report and the supporting documents submitted by the fiscal regarding the existence of probable cause, and on the basis thereof, issue a warrant of arrest. If on the basis thereof he finds no probable cause, he may disregard the fiscal’s report and require the submission of additional supporting affidavits of witnesses to aid him in arriving at a conclusion.

b. However, in case of SEARCH WARRANT, the judge must personally examine the complainant and his witnesses through searching questions in accordance with Sections 3 and 4 of Rule 126 of Rules of Criminal Procedure.

children.name: Silva vs. Presiding Judge of RTC, Negros Oriental
children.enum1: The deposition was already mimeogragphed and all that the witnesses had to do was fill in their answers on the blanks provided. Mere generalization will not suffice and does not satisfy the requirements of probable cause upon which a warrant may issue. The judge must examine the witness in the form of searching questions and answer. The same must be probing and exhaustive, and not merely general, routinary, and perfunctory.

Orders of arrest may be issued by administrative agencies but only for the purpose of carrying out a final finding of a violation of law, and not for the sole purpose of investigation and prosecution.
children.enum2: The Constitutional limitations contemplates an order of arrest in the exercise of judicial power as a step preliminary or incidental to prosecution, but not as a measure indispensable to carry out a valid decision by a competent official.

children.enum1: The determination of propriety of deportation is not a prosecution for, or conviction of a crime, nor is the deportation a punishment, even though the facts underlying the decision may constitute a crime under local law.
children.enum2: The constitutional guarantee against issuance of warrant of arrest upon probable cause to be determined by the judge does not extend to deportation proceedings.

children.name: Harvey vs. Santiago
children.enum1: Under the 1987 Constitution, Administrative warrants are valid as long as they are not for prosecution purposes.
Warrants for the arrest of undesirable aliens may be issued by the Commissioner of Immigration to enforce a final decision of deportation.
children.enum2: The deportation proceedings are administrative in character, summary in nature, and need not be conducted strictly in accordance with the ordinary court proceedings. It is however sufficient that the alien shall be given sufficient information about the charges against him, and a fair hearing.

children.enum1: Judicial controversies need not to be observed only such as are fundamental and essential like cross-examination. Hearsay evidence may also be admitted provided that the alien is given the opportunity to explain it.

children.name: Salazar vs. Achacoso
children.enum1: The Secretary of Labor, not being a judge, cannot issue warrants and the provision in the Labor Code empowering the Secretary to issue warrants is unconstitutional.

children.name: Alvarez vs. CFI
children.details: Search warrant by Police based on Reliable Source
children.enum1: SC: Test of sufficient oath - drawn in such a manner that falsity results in conviction of perjury.
children.enum2: Based on reliable source - affiant cannot be held liable for perjury
children.enum3: Personal knowledge is necessary as the rules on evidence requires it.

children.name: Particularity
children.enum1: Documents related to lending business

children.name: Definition of Oath
children.enum1: any form of attestation by which a party signifies that he is bound in conscience to perform an act faithfully and truthfully; and it is sometimes defined as an outward pledge given by the person taking it that his attestation or promise is made under an immediate sense of his responsibility to God

Probable cause must be based on personal knowledge of the complainant or his witnesses. But in issuing warrants, witnesses are not necessary as long as the probable cause is sufficiently established by the complainant within his direct and personal knowledge; but when applicant’s knowledge is mere hearsay, the affidavit of one or more witnesses having personal knowledge is necessary.

What constitutes a reasonable or unreasonable search or seizure in any particular case is a purely judicial question, determinable from a consideration of the circumstances involved, including the purpose of the search, the presence or absence of probable cause, the manner in which the search and seizure was made, the place or thing searched, and the character of the articles procured
A search may be made at NIGHT if it is positively asserted in the affidavit that the property is on the person or in the place ordered to be searched.
The warrant is unconstitutional if it was issued for the sole purpose of seizing evidence which would later be used in criminal proceedings.

While the detailed description of the person and place to be searched and articles to be seized is necessary, where by the nature of the articles to be seized must be rather in general, it is not required that a technical description be given.

children.name: Mata vs. Bayona
children.enum1: For search warrants, depositions are necessary in order that the Judge may be able to properly determine the existence of probable cause, and to hold liable for perjury the person giving it if it will be found later that his declarations are false. Hence, mere affidavits of the complainant and his witnesses are not sufficient. The Judge must take depositions in writing and attach them to the records of the case.

children.name: People vs. Del Rosario
children.enum1: Officers serving the warrant may only seize the objects described therein. And that the police authorities have no authority to seize an article not mentioned in the warrant.
children.enum2: A search warrant is not a sweeping authority empowering the raiding party to undertake a fishing expedition and to confiscate all and any kinds of evidence related to a crime.

children.name: Particularity
children.enum1: Determined in the face of the warrant. The police officer may not augment what is written.

children.name: Can the police officer seize an unlicensed firearm in a search for illegal drugs?
children.enum1: They can seize it, but it may not be used as evidence for prosecution for a crime for possession of unlicensed firearm

children.details: A peace officer or a private person may, without a warrant, arrest a person:
children.enum1: (1) When, in his presence, the person to be arrested has committed, is actually committing, or is attempting to commit an offense;
children.enum2: (2) When an offense has just been committed, and he has probable cause to believe based on personal knowledge of facts or circumstances that the person to be arrested has committed it; and
children.enum3: (3) When the person to be arrested is a prisoner who has escaped from a penal establishment or place where he is serving final judgment or is temporarily confined while his case is pending, or has escaped while being transferred from one confinement to another.

children.enum1: A person lawfully arrested may be searched for dangerous weapons or anything which may have been used or constitute proof in the commission of an offense without a search warrant.
children.enum2: The frisk and search of a person upon arrest was a permissible measure of arresting officers to protect themselves, for the person who is about to be arrested may be armed and might attack them unless he is disarmed.

children.name: Umil vs. Ramos
children.enum1: Arrest may be made at any time against persons charged with continuing crime.

children.name: People vs. Sucro
children.enum1: An offense is committed within the presence of the officer even if the latter is at a distance when he sees the offense, or hears the disturbance created thereby and proceeds at once to the scene of the crime.
children.enum2: Physical presence is not required provided other senses are operative. But physical presence is not enough without any showing that they are conscious of what was happening around.

children.name: People vs. Rodrigueza
children.enum1: Agents could not have justified their act by invoking the urgency and necessity of the situation since the witnesses reveal that the place had already been put under surveillance for quite some time. Had it been their intention to conduct the raid, then they should have first secured a search warrant.

children.name: Go. Vs. Court of Appeals
children.enum1: A person cannot be arrested without a warrant for an offense committed six days earlier. None of the arresting officers had any personal knowledge of the facts indicating that petitioner was the gunman. The information upon which police acted had been derived from the statements made by an alleged eyewitness. That information did not, however, constitute a personal knowledge.
A lawful search without a warrant may be made even without being preceded by an arrest as in the case of stop and search.
children.enum2: Not all searches and seizures are prohibited. Those which are reasonable are not forbidden. A reasonable search is not to be determined by a fixed formula but is to be resolved according to the facts of each case.

children.enum1: Between the inherent right of the State to protect and promote public welfare, and an individual right against warrantless search which is however reasonably conducted, the former shall prevail.
children.enum2: d. The assailed search and seizure may still be justified as akin to a stop and frisk situation whose object is either to determine the identity of a suspicious individual or maintain a status quo momentarily while police officers seek to obtain more information. It is reasonable for an officer rather than simply to shrug his shoulder and allow a crime to occur.

children.name: People vs. Mengote
children.enum1: There is nothing to support the arresting officer’s suspicion other than Mengote’s darting eyes and his hand on abdomen. By no stretch of imagination could it have been inferred that an offense had just been committed, or he was actually committing an offense. In short, there was no probable cause.

Any evidence obtained as a result of an illegal search or seizure is inadmissible in any proceeding for any purpose. This is the celebrated Exclusionary Rule based on the justification that only in cases the prosecution, which itself controls the seizing official, knows that it cannot profit by their wrong will the wrong be repressed.
In a search incidental to lawful arrest, the law requires that there first be a lawful arrest before a search. The process cannot be reversed.

In stop and frisk, where the police has genuine reason to believe and observes an unusual conduct which leads him reasonably to conclude in light of his experience, and surrounding situations, he is entitled for the protection for himself and others to conduct a carefully limited search of the outer clothing of such person.

children.details: The two-fold interests of stop and frisk are:
children.enum1: (1) General interest for effective crime prevention and detection; and
children.enum2: (2) More pressing interest of safety and self-preservation.

children.name: People vs. Aminnudin
children.enum1: Expediency cannot be invoked to dispense with the obtention of the warrant. They had at least two days within which to obtain a warrant. His name was known. The vehicle is identified. The date of the arrival is certain. And from these information, they could easily persuade a Judge to issue them a warrant. Yet, they did nothing. No effort was made to comply with the law.

As demanding as the campaign against drug addiction may be, it cannot be more so than the compulsions of the Bill of Rights for the protection of the liberty of every individual in the realm, including the basest of criminals.

children.name: People vs. Malmstedt
children.enum1: The warrantless search of the personal effects of an accused has been declared valid because of the smell of marijuana, suspicious action, and an attempt to flee. NARCOM agents also received information that vehicles coming from Sagada were transporting Marijuana, and their Commanding Officer also received an Information that a Caucasian on that particular day had prohibited drugs in his possession. When NARCOM received the information, a few hours before the apprehension, there was not enough time to obtain a warrant.

children.name: Luz vs. People
children.enum1: The general procedure for dealing with a traffic violation is not the arrest of the offender, but the confiscation of the driver’s license of the latter. The apprehending officer must immediately issue a Traffic Violation Report and not indulge in prolonged, unnecessary conversation or argument with the driver.

children.name: Espano vs. Court of Appeals
children.enum1: A search incidental to a lawful arrest may be extended to premises within the immediate control of the person arrested.

children.details: The seizure by the officer of objects not described in the warrant cannot be presumed as plain view. The State must adduce evidence, to prove the confluence of the essential requirement for the doctrine to apply, to wit:
children.enum1: (1) Valid intrusion of officers in compliance with their legal duties;
children.enum2: (2) Officer must discover the incriminating object inadvertently; and
children.enum3: (3) It must be immediately apparent to the police that the item may be evidence of a crime.

children.enum1: Inadvertence means that the officer must not have known in advance of the location of the evidence and intend to seize it. Discovery must not be anticipated.

The Immediately Apparent Test does not require an unduly high degree of certainty as to incriminating character of evidence. It requires merely that the seizure be presumptively reasonable assuming that there is probable cause to associate the property with criminal activity; that a Nexus exists between a viewed object and criminal activity.

children.name: Papa vs. Mago
children.enum1: The Tariff and Customs Code does not require a search warrant for purposes of enforcing customs and tariff laws. Any person having police authority may enforce the search and seizure against dutiable items or prohibited articles that were imported in the Philippines, anywhere, except dwelling houses.

children.name: People vs. Musa
children.enum1: The Plain View Doctrine may not be used to launch unbridled searches and indiscriminate seizures nor to extend a general exploratory search made solely to find evidence of defendant’s guilt.
children.enum2: It cannot be said that the plastic bag clearly betrayed its contents, whether by its distinctive configurations, transparency or otherwise its contents are obvious to an observer. Hence, the doctrine of plain view cannot be applied.

children.enum1: Not having raised the legality of his arrest before entering his plea, he is deemed to have waived the illegality of the same. Note, however that, this waiver is LIMITED TO THE ARREST. It does NOT extend to the search made.

The conspicuous illegality of arrest cannot affect the jurisdiction of the trial court, because even in the instances not allowed by law, a warrantless arrest is not a jurisdictional defect, and any objection thereto is waived when the person arrested submits to arraignment without any objection.

True that the manning of checkpoints by the military is susceptible of abuse. But at the cost of occasional inconvenience, discomfort, and even irritation to the citizen, the checkpoints during abnormal times, when conducted within reasonable limits are part of the price we pay for an orderly society and peaceful community.

Petitioner’s general allegation to the effect that he had been stopped and searched without a search warrant, and without stating the details of the incident amounting to violation of his rights is NOT sufficient to enable the Court to determine whether there was a violation of right against searches and seizure. Not all searches and seizures are prohibited. Those which are reasonable are not forbidden.

children.name: Section 3
children.enum1: (1) The privacy of communication and correspondence shall be inviolable except upon lawful order of the court, or when public safety or order requires otherwise as prescribed by law.
children.enum2: (2) Any evidence obtained in violation of this or the preceding section shall be inadmissible for any purpose in any proceeding.

children.name: Section 4
children.enum1: No law shall be passed abridging the freedom of speech, of expression, or of the press, or the right of the people peaceably to assemble and petition the government for redress of grievances.
